It is in two sections. His aim here is to show the nature of the disagreements that can be found in books on anatomy by earlier authors on the topic either in relation to matters of terminology alone or to matters of theory, and to suggest reasons for these.

Dissection of Dead Animals ( K. tashrīḥ al-amwāt ).
De anatomia mortuorum . Fichtner 169. Cf. Ḥunayn al-ḥayawān al-mayyit .
It consists of a single section. In this he describes the kind of things we can learn from dissecting a dead animal.

Dissection of Living Animals ( K. tashrīḥ al-aḥyāʾ ).
De anatomia vivorum . Fichtner 171. Cf. Ḥunayn al-ḥayawān al-hayy .
It is in two sections. His aim here is to show what kind of things we can learn by dissecting a living animal.

Hippocrates’ Knowledge of Anatomy ( K. fī ʿilm Abuqrāṭ bi-l-tashrīh ).
De Hippocratis anatomia . Fichtner 243. See 5.1.14 (with a different title).
Galen arranged the book in five sections. He wrote it at as a young man for Boethus
For Boethus, see n. 53.
and his aim in it was to show that Hippocrates was faithful to the science of anatomy. He cites testimonia from across his corpus.

Erasistratus’ Views on Anatomy ( K. fī ārāʾ Arāsisṭrāṭus bi-l-tashrīḥ ).
De Erasistrati anatomia . Fichtner 229.
Galen composed the book in three sections. He wrote it as a young man, also for Boethus, and his aim was to explain Erasistratus’ discussion of anatomy in the course of his works and to show where he was right and where he went wrong.

Gaps in Lycus’ Knowledge of Anatomy ( K. fīmā lam yaʿlamhu Lūqus min amr al-tashrīḥ ).
De ignoratis Lyco in dissectionibus . Fichtner 250, Sezgin,
GAS
III , 134 no. 134.
It is in four sections.

Disagreements with Lycus about Anatomy ( K. fīmā khālafa fīhi li-Lūqus fi l-tashrīḥ ).
Adversus Lycum . Fichtner 103*.
It is in two sections.

Anatomy of the Womb ( K. fī tashrīḥ al-raḥim ).
De uteri dissectione . Fichtner 16*.
This book consists of a single short section. He wrote it as a young man for a midwife. It contains all one needs to know about the anatomy of the womb and what is generated in it during pregnancy.

The First Vertebral Articulation of the Spinal Column ( K. fī mafṣil al-fiqrah al-ūlā min fiqār al-raqabah ).
Not in Fichtner, Ullmann, Sezgin, or Ibn al-Qifṭī, Ibn al-Nadīm, or Ḥunayn recension ‘B’.
It consists of a single section.

Differences in the Homoeomerous Parts ( K. fī khtilāf al-aʿḍāʾ al-mutashābihat al-ajzāʾ ).
De partium homoeomerium differentia . Fichtner 247. CMG Suppl. Or. III (ed. Strohmaier).
It consists of a single section.

Anatomy of the Organs of the Voice ( K. fī tashrīḥ ālāt al-ṣawt ).
De dissectione vocalium instrumentorum . Fichtner 441.
It consists of a single section. Ḥunayn notes that ‘this book is forged after the style of Galen but is not by him or any of the ancients. Rather, it is the work of a modern author who compiled it from Galen’s books and was,’ more to the point, ‘rather poor.’

Anatomy of the Eye ( K. fī tashrīḥ al-ʿayn ).
De oculis . Fichtner 287.
It is also in one section. Ḥunayn notes that ‘the title is again fictional since it is attributed to Galen’ and is not by Galen. ‘It is likely it is by Rufus or someone inferior to him.’

Movement of the Chest and Lungs ( K. fī ḥarakat al-ṣadr wa-l-riʾah ).
De motu thoracis et pulmonis . Fichtner 280.
He composed this book in three sections. He wrote it as a young man after he returned from Rome for the first time and was then resident in Smyrna under Pelops.
Galen studied with Pelops in Smyrna not long after 149. See n. 160. The information here (from Ḥunayn) represents a confused reading of On My Own Books 2, where the context is Galen’s travel from Pergamum to Smyrna, and Galen speaks of books presented to him upon his arrival that he had written before he went to study with Pelops or, in the case of the Movement of Chest and Lungs , that he wrote during his study with him.
Indeed it was a fellow pupil who asked him for it. In the first two sections and the beginning of the third he sets out what he learnt from his teacher Pelops on this topic. In the remainder of the third section he outlines his own discoveries.

Causes of Breathing ( K. fī ʿilal al-tanaffus ).
De causis respirationis . Fichtner 20*. Cf. no. 137.
He composed this book in two sections for Boethus on his first trip to Rome. His aim in both is to explain which organs give rise to breathing that is automatic and which breathing that is forced.
In Recension ‘B’ this reads: ‘which organs give rise to breathing, both that which is automatic and that which is forced’.

The Voice ( K. fī l-ṣawt ).
De voce . Fichtner 358. Cf. 5.1.10.1.
This book in four sections was composed after the book I have just mentioned. The aim is to show the origins of the voice, its character, its material, the organs that produce it, which parts of the body assist in its production, and how voices differ.

The Movement of the Muscles ( K. fī ḥarakat al-ʿaḍal ).
De motu musculorum . Fichtner 19*.
It is in two sections. His aim is to show the nature of the movement of the muscles, its workings, and the origin of these different movements in muscle even though their movement is unitary. He also investigates whether breath is voluntary or the result of natural movements and engages in a wide-ranging and sophisticated enquiry on the topic.

Criticism of the Error Held Regarding the Distinction Between Urine and Blood ( M. fī munāqaḍat al-khaṭaʾ alladhī ʿtuqid fī tamyīz al-bawl min al-dam ).
Not in Fichtner.

The Necessity of the Pulse ( M. fī l-ḥājah ilā l-nabḍ ).
De usu pulsuum . Fichtner 32*.

The Necessity of Breathing ( M. fī l-ḥājah ilā l-tanaffus ).
De usu respirationis . Fichtner 21*.

Is There or Is There Not a Natural Flow of Blood in the Arteries ( M. fī l-ʿurūq al-ḍawārib hal yajrī fīhā l-dam bi-l-ṭabʿ am lā )?
An in arteriis sanguis natura contineatur ? Fichtner 24*.

Properties of Laxative Drugs ( K. fī quwā l-adwiyah al-mus′hilah ).
De purgantium medicamentorum facultate . Fichtner 75* (cf. 185 on the Ps.-Galen De catharticis ; but the entry here is for the genuine work). The Arabic for ‘properties’ ( quwā ; sg. quwwah ) is often translated ‘power(s)’ according to the traditional rendering of Greek dunamis , ‘power’, ‘faculty’. In contexts such as the present one it refers to what is inherent in a drug or foodstuff that gives it the potential or capacity to bring about change or cause, assist and complete a therapy through its ‘power’ to cool or warm, cause scarring, cleansing, diuresis, promote a particular humour, and so on. It offers an important way to organize materia medica , as we see it for example in Dioscorides or Galen’s De alimentorum facultatibus (title 121) and De simplicium medicamentorum temperamentis et facultatibus (title 53). For this sense we use ‘property’. But where quwwah refers to a general bodily process such as digestion or growth, it is translated as ‘faculty’.
It consists of a single section. He shows that the laxative effects of drugs and what they purge does not come about because any of these drugs change matter they encounter in the body into its own nature, thereby causing it to be expelled and pass out. Rather each of them attracts to itself a humour that is compatible and consistent with itself.

Habits ( K. fī l-ʿādāt ).
De consuetudinibus . Fichtner 202*. The appendix is not preserved. Arabic at ‘Graeco-Arabic-Studies’ (ed. Klein-Franke; German translation also at CMG Supp. Or. III trans. Pfaff).
It consists of a single section. His aim is to show that habit is one of the factors that should be taken into account. A supplement and appendix to the book is formed by a commentary on Galen’s citations on the topic from the text of Plato according to the interpretation of Proclus
Bergsträsser (recension ‘A’) and Müller read Herophilus, the great physician of the early 3rd c. BC , with the sense that citations from Plato in Galen’s work were interpreted through extracts from a commentary by Herophilus. No such work is attested in the Greek tradition (cf. von Staden, Herophilus ) and the name in the MSS is better interpreted as Proclus (cf. Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq, Neue Materialen , 19 and Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq, Galen Translations , 58–59 for recension ‘B’). IAU ’s text is perhaps closer to Herophilus than Proclus. However, though he probably mentions Herophilus briefly at Ch. 4.1.10.5, he would have had little idea who he was, whereas the Neoplatonist Proclus was known. The section of the commentary by Proclus on Timaeus 89e–90c (cf. De consuetudinibus p. 26 ed. Schmutte, CMG Suppl. III ) that is preserved in Arabic has been translated by Pfaff ( De consuetudinibus , CMG Suppl. III , pp. 53–60).
and a commentary on citations from the text of Hippocrates according to the interpretation of Galen.

The Opinions of Hippocrates and Plato ( K. fī ārāʾ Abuqrāṭ wa-Falāṭun ).
De placitis Hippocratis et Platonis . Fichtner 33*.
It is in ten sections. His aim is to show that Plato is consistent with Hippocrates in the majority of his views since he borrows most of them from him, and that where Aristotle diverges from them, he is wrong. He explains everything one needs to know about the soul as the governing faculty responsible for thought, imagination, and memory, and of the three roots that are the sources of the faculties responsible for governing the body.
These ‘roots’ (Arabic uṣūl , Greek ἀρχαί) refer to the archē (‘origin’ or ‘principle’) of (i) motion/sensation in the brain (working through the nerves), (ii) blood and nutrition and appetite in the liver (acting through the veins), and (iii) the vital ( zōtikē ) force in the heart (functioning through the arteries). See Hankinson, ‘Galen’s Anatomy of the Soul’ on his location of the Platonic tripartite soul in these organs.
He discusses various other topics as well.

Problematical Movement ( K. fī l-ḥarakah al-muʿtāṣah ).
De motibus dubiis . Fichtner 279. The Arabic is edited by Bos in Nutton & Bos, On Problematical Movements .
It consists of a single section. His aim is to examine movements which neither he nor his predecessors had been aware of but which he later managed to understand.

The Organ of Smell ( K. fī ālat al-shamm ).
De instrumento odoratus . Fichtner 15*.
It consists of a single section.

The Uses of the Parts ( K. manāfiʿ al-aʿḍāʾ ).
De usu partium . Fichtner 17* and 18*.
It is in seventeen sections. In sections one and two he shows us the wisdom of the Creator (He is Blessed and Exalted!) in perfecting the creation of the hand and arm.
Arabic yad may signify both English terms and the translation here reflects the contents of the book.
In the third section he shows his wisdom in perfecting the foot and leg,
Arabic rijl may signify both English terms and both are treated in De usu partium 3.
in sections four and five his wisdom regarding the organs used for nutrition. He takes sections six and seven on the subject of the organs used in breathing, and in eight and nine he focusses on the inside of the head. In ten he treats the eyes and in eleven the other features of the face. In section twelve he discusses the parts of the body that are associated with the head and neck. In thirteen he turns to the areas near to the spine and shoulder blades. In the two following sections he describes the Creator’s wisdom at work in the parts of the body responsible for reproduction. Then in section sixteen he considers organs common to the whole body such as arteries, veins and nerves. In seventeen he describes the disposition and proportions of all parts of the body and demonstrates the usefulness of the entire book.

The Best Constitution for the Body ( M. fī afḍal hayʾāt al-badan ).
De optima corporis nostri constitutione . Fichtner 25*.
This treatise is a sequel to the first two sections of Mixtures .
Cf. Ch. 6.3.2.
The aim is clear from the title.

Bodily Vigour ( M. fī khiṣb al-badan ).
De bono habitu . Fichtner 26*. ‘Vigour’ perhaps suits Greek euexia better than Arabic khiṣb which indicates fatness or plumpness; cf 14.27.4 no. 4.
A minor treatise. The aim is clear from the title.

Uneven Bad Mixture ( M. fī sūʾ al-mizāj al-mukhtalif ).
De inaequali intemperie . Fichtner 58*.
The aim is clear from the title. In it he discusses which type of bad mixture occurs evenly throughout the body, and how it affects one’s condition, and which type is uneven through the parts of the body.

Simple Drugs ( K. al-adwiyah al-mufradah ).
De simplicium medicamentorum temperamentis et facultatibus . Fichtner 78* and 79*.
He arranged this book in eleven sections. In the first two of these he exposes the mistakes people have made by using poor methods to evaluate the properties of drugs. After this, in section three he provides a solid basis for the whole discipline of evaluating the primary properties of drugs. Section four clarifies secondary properties such as tastes or smells and informs us how to deduce from these the primary properties of drugs. In section five he describes the tertiary properties of drugs, i.e. the effects of warming, cooling, drying, or moistening that are produced by them in the body. In the three sections that follow he describes the property of each of the drugs that are pieces of plants. Next in section nine he examines the properties of drugs that are parts of the earth, i.e. types of soil, clay, stone, or minerals. In section ten he looks at drugs that come from materials produced in the bodies of living creatures, and in eleven describes the properties of drugs that come from materials generated in the sea or salt water.

Signs of Ailments in the Eyes ( M. fī dalāʾil ʿilal al-ʿayn ).
De morbis oculorum et eorum curis . Fichtner 275.
He wrote it in his youth for a young man who was an oculist.
Cf. On My Own Books 2.3.
He gives a brief account of the ailments that afflict each of the tunics of the eye and describes their signs.

Times in Diseases ( M. fī awqāt al-amrāḍ ).
De morborum temporibus . Fichtner 49*.
The subject of his enquiry is the four phases of a disease, i.e. its outbreak, advance, peak, and decline.

Fullness ( K. al-imtilāʾ ), also known as Plethora ( K. al-kathrah ).
De plenitudine . Fichtner 53*.
It consists of a single section in which he outlines the topic of an abundance in the humours. He describes these and the signs of each type.

Swellings ( M. fī l-awrām ).
De tumoribus praeter naturam . Fichtner 57*.
Galen defined them as types of unnatural hard masses. In this treatise he describes all types of swellings and their signs.

Apparent Causes ( M. fī l-asbāb al-bādiyah ),
De causis procatarcticis . Fichtner 188.
i.e. swellings ( al-awrām ), which occur
It seems that Ḥunayn’s ‘initial’ ( bādiʾah ) has been misinterpreted as ‘apparent’ ( bādiyah ) in IAU or his copy of the Risālah , an easy change in Arabic. The corruption was assisted by the change of Ḥunayn’s ‘primary’ ( al-uwal ) to IAU ’s ‘swellings’ ( al-awrām , cf. title no. 57), thereby signalling something visible.
on the exterior of the body. In this treatise he demonstrates the effect of apparent causes on the body and the deficient arguments of those who dismiss their effect.

Cohesive Causes in Diseases ( M. fī l-asbāb al-muttaṣilah bi-l-amrāḍ ).
De causis contentivis . Fichtner 187. Arabic at CMG Suppl. Or. II (ed. Lyons).
In this he discusses the cohesive cause of disease, i.e. its efficient cause.
Using a Stoicizing vocabulary Galen split the Aristotelian idea of an efficient cause into three. The ‘cohesive cause’ (συνεκτικὸν αἴτιον νοσήματος) was the state in which a body part malfunctioned and produced e.g. excess. It worked with an ‘antecedent’ cause ( causa antecedens ), which was the patient’s predisposition to a particular weakness, and an ‘initial’ cause ( causa procatarctica ), which was an external trigger such as heat or injury, to bring about a disease.

Tremor, Spasm, Convulsion and Shivering ( M. fī l-riʿshah wa-l-nāfiḍ wa-l-ikhtilāj wa-l-tashannuj ).
De tremore, palpitatione, convulsione et rigore . Fichtner 54*.

Parts of Medicine ( M. fī ajzāʾ al-ṭibb ).
De partibus artis medicativae . Fichtner 291. Arabic at CMG Suppl. Or. II (ed. Lyons).
He divides medicine by various modes of division and subdivision.

Sperm ( K. fī l-manī ).
De semine . Fichtner 22*.
It consists of two sections. His aim is to show that it is not blood that is responsible for generating all parts of the body, as Aristotle had thought. Rather, all the elementary parts of the body,
See n. 261.
that is, the pale parts, are generated from sperm, whereas it is the dark flesh alone that is generated from the blood of the menses.

Generation of the Fetus Born at Seven Months ( M. fī tawallud al-janīn al-mawlūd li-sabʿat ashhur ).
De septimestri partu . Fichtner 323. Arabic at ‘Graeco-Arabic-Studies’ (ed. Walzer).

Black Bile ( M. fī l-mirrah al-sawdāʾ ).
De atra bile . Fichtner 31*.
In this he describes types and signs of black bile.

Periods and Compositions of Fevers ( K. adwār al-ḥummayāt wa-tarākībihā ).
Ad eos qui de typis scripserunt . Fichtner 52*.
It consists of one section. In it he criticizes people who assert that there is no value in the topic of periods and compositions of fevers. Galen’s title for the book was “Criticism of Those who Discuss Types” ( Munāqaḍat man takallama fī l-rusūm ). Ḥunayn says, ‘Another treatise on the topic is extant but it is not by Galen.’

Epitome of the so-called Great Book of the Pulse ( Ikhtiṣār kitābihi l-maʿrūf bi-l-nabḍ al-kabīr ).
See no. 16 and Synopsis de pulsibus , Fichtner 66*. Cf. Sezgin,
GAS
III , 93–94 suggesting on the evidence of Rhazes that the Arabic translation of no. 66, which Ḥunayn regarded as supposititious, was completed at a later date.
It consists of one section. Galen states that he gave a comprehensive summary of the pulse in this book. Ḥunayn says that, ‘I have seen in Greek a treatise
Ḥunayn gives the title as Summary ( jumlah ) of the Great Book of the Pulse .
along these lines. However, I cannot accept that Galen is the author of the treatise since it does not include all the essential facts about the pulse and moreover its composition is unattractive. It is possible that Galen had promised to write this treatise
Cf. the early work, Ars medica , i.410 Kühn.
but was unable to do so, and when a forger noticed the promise was unfulfilled he fabricated the authorship of the work and inserted a mention of it in his Catalogue
Here fihrist , i.e. De libris propriis 8.5.
so it would be accepted. It is also possible that Galen did write a treatise on this topic (but not this one), that it went missing like many of his books, and so this treatise was concocted as a substitute in its place.’

On the Pulse in Criticism of Archigenes ( K. fī l-nabḍ yunāqiḍu fīhi Arkhījānis ).
Archigenis tractationis de pulsibus expositio et censura . Fichtner 148; but see Boudon-Millot, Galien for the correct title (κρίσις not χρῆσις as Fichtner has it as if it were ‘expositio et usus’). Cf. n. 257.
Galen says he wrote it in eight sections.

Difficulty in Breathing ( K. fī radāʾat al-tanaffus ).
De difficultate respirationis . Fichtner 59*.
He wrote the book in three sections. His aim is to describe the types and causes of difficult breathing and what they signify. In the first section he describes types and causes of breathing, in the second types of difficult breathing and what each means, and in the third section he cites passages of Hippocrates that confirm the validity of his argument.

Remarkable Stories of Prognosis ( K. nawādir taqdimat al-maʿrifah ).
De praenotione ad Epigenem . Fichtner 88*. Cf. 5.1.28.
It consists of one section. In this he makes the case for prognosis, informs us about the ingenious methods that lie behind it and describes and illustrates spectacular examples of it from his patients. Once these became known, he was much admired.

Abridgment of his Method of Healing ( Ikhtiṣār K. fī ḥīlat al-burʾ ).
Synopsis methodi medendi . Fichtner 434.
It consists of two sections.

Phlebotomy ( K. al-fasḍ ).
This work is an amalgam of three separate treatises: De venae sectione adversus Erasistratum , De venae sectione adversus Erasistrateos Romae degentes , and De curandi ratione per venae sectionem (Fichtner * 71, * 72, * 73). There is no reason to hold it = De venae sectione (Fichtner 125*), which is usually regarded as spurious (cf. Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq, Galen Translations 161–162).
It consists of three sections. Section one is intended as an attack on Erasistratus for his opposition to phlebotomy. In the second section he attacks his followers at Rome for the same notion. In the third he gives his own views about treatment by means of phlebotomy.

On the Wasting Disease ( K. al-dhubūl ).
De marasmo . Fichtner 56*.
It consists of one section. The aim is to show the nature and types of this disease and the regimen appropriate for people at risk.

Prescriptions for an Epileptic Boy ( M. fī ṣifāt li-ṣabīy yuṣraʿ ).
Puero epileptico consilium . Fichtner 77*.

Properties of Foods ( K. quwā l-aghdhiyah ).
De alimentorum facultatibus . Fichtner 38*.
It consists of three sections. He lists all foods and drinks that are sources of nourishment and describes the properties each contains.

The Thinning Diet ( K. al-tadbīr al-mulaṭṭif ).
De victu attenuante . Fichtner 349*.
It consists of one section. The aim accords with the title.
list.label: 75a.
list.item:
An abridgment of this book on the thinning diet. It consists of one section.
IAU has misunderstood Ḥunayn’s Risālah at this point. To entry 75 someone has added, ‘This is among the items he [i.e. Ḥunayn] summarized …’ There is no evidence of a summary made by Galen or for ‘an anonymous Summary ’ (Sezgin,
GAS
III , 118).

Good and Bad Juices ( K. al-Kaymūs al-jayyid wa-l-radīʾ ).
De bonis malisque sucis . Fichtner 39*. See 5.1.24, with n. 154.
It consists of one section. He lists foods and reviews which of them produce excellent or bad juices.

Erasistratus’ Theory of Treating Disease ( K. fī afkār Arāsisṭrāṭus fī mudāwāt al-amrāḍ ).
De Erasistrati curandi ratione . Fichtner 230.
It consists of eight
An error for ‘five’: Boudon-Millot, Galien , 209.
sections. He considers Erasistratus’ therapeutic methods and distinguishes correct approaches from erroneous ones.

Regimen in Acute Diseases according to the Views of Hippocrates ( K. tadbīr al-amrāḍ al-ḥāddah ʿalā raʾy Abuqrāṭ ).
De diaeta in morbis acutis secundum Hippocratem . Fichtner 118 (but beware of confusion in this entry); Arabic at CMG Suppl. Or. II (ed. Lyons, whose introduction pp. 12–21 should be consulted). Not to be confounded (as Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq, Galen Translations 162) with the Ps.-Galenic De diaeta Hippocratis in morbis acutis ( De victus ratione in morbis acutis ex Hippocratis sententia ), which survives in Greek (ed. Westenberger; also Fichtner 118*), or the genuine In Hippocratis de victu acutorum commentarii (ed. Helmreich; Fichtner 93*; see no. 92 below).

item.p:
Composition of Drugs ( K. tarkīb al-adwiyah ). He wrote it in seventeen sections. In seven of these he gives a comprehensive account of the varieties ( ajnās ) of compound drugs and lists them by one by one. For example, he includes the variety of drugs that is specifically for building up flesh in the case of ulcers, the variety that is solely for dissolving, and the variety that produces scarring, and so on and so forth for all the other varieties of drugs. The aim is to describe the method of compounding drugs in groups ( jumal ). For this reason he gave these seven sections the title Composition of Drugs by Groups and Varieties .
De compositione medicamentorum per genera . Fichtner 82*.
To the other ten sections he gave the title Composition of Drugs by Places .
De compositione medicamentorum secundum locos . Fichtner 80* and 81*.
What he meant is this. When he calls these ten sections Composition of Drugs , he is not suggesting that each type of drug will produce its effect on a disease under any circumstances but that it does so in relation to the place – i.e. the part of the body – where the disease is present. He starts with the head and then proceeds in order through all parts of the body till the last.

I
IAU .
say that a complete version of this book, which Galen designated Composition of Drugs , is not to be found today. Rather it has been divided into two books and each of them is independent. There is not much doubt that the Alexandrians did this relying on their clear understanding of Galen’s works, but it could have been others. Thus the first portion is known as the Qāṭājānis ,
I.e. from the Greek title kata genos .
and includes the first seven sections mentioned above. The second is known as the Mayāmir .
The Arabic term is based on the Syriac mēmar , ‘treatise’ (not al-ṭarīq , ‘way’, as IAU has it).
It comprises the remaining ten sections. Mayāmir is the plural of mīmar , which means “way”. The book was probably given this name because it shows the way to employ compound drugs in the correct manner.

list.item:
Readily Available Drugs ( K. al-adwiyah allatī yas′hulu wujūduhā ).
De remediis parabilibus . Fichtner 86* (Ps.-Galen).
These are the drugs that are termed “locally available”. The book consists of two sections. Ḥunayn says that, ‘An additional section on this subject was added to it and attributed to Galen but in fact it is by Philagrius’.
Perhaps cf. title no. 1 in the list of works by Philagrius, below 5.2.2. We retain the form of the name in ABR (with bāʾ ), which could point to a different recension from readings using a fāʾ .
He also says that ‘a great deal of nonsense’ has been inserted ‘into the book including novel and surprising prescriptions and drugs that Galen had never seen or heard of.’

Drugs that Counter Diseases ( K. al-adwiyah al-muqābilah li-l-adwāʾ ).
De antidotis . Fichtner 83*.
He wrote it in two sections. In section one his subject is theriac, in section two he covers all other medicinal pastes.
I.e. here antidotes; cf. Ullmann,
WGAÜ
s.v. ἀντίδοτος.

Theriac to Pamphilianus ( K. al-tiryāq ilā Bamfūliyānūs ).
De theriaca ad Pamphilianum . Fichtner 85*. Ps-Galenic.
It consists of one short section.

Theriac to Piso ( K. al-tiryāq ilā Fīsun ).
De theriaca ad Pisonem . Fichtner 84*.
This is also consists of one section.

Method for Preserving Health ( K. fī l-ḥīlah li-ḥifẓ al-ṣiḥḥah ).
De sanitate tuenda . Fichtner 37*.
It consists of six sections. His aim is to show how healthy people can preserve their health, including those who are in the peak of health and those who are not, and those who live a free live and those who live a slave’s.

To Thrasybulus ( K. ilā Barāthīlūs ).
Thrasybulus sive utrum medicinae sit an gymnasticae hygiene . Fichtner 34*.
It consists of one section. The aim is to investigate whether healthy people preserve their health ‮becau‎se of the art of medicine or as a result of the art of the professional trainers. This is the work he refers to at the start of his book Regimen for Healthy People ( K. tadbīr al-aṣiḥḥāʾ )
This description of the De sanitate tuenda is also used as an alternative title for it in Arabic (so in Risālah recension ‘B’): Sezgin,
GAS
III , 112 no. 69, below Ch. 3.3. The reference to Thrasybulus comes at the very start (vi.1 ed. Kühn).
where he says that ‘there is a single art that is responsible for bodies, as I have shown elsewhere’.

Exercise with a Small Ball ( K. al-riyāḍah bi-l-kurah al-ṣaghīrah ).
De parvae pilae exercitio . Fichtner 35*.
It consists of one section. In it he commends exercise with a small ball and play using a mallet
There is no ‘play using a mallet’ in De parvae pilae exercitio itself. Ḥunayn is alluding to a contemporary game played with the ṣawlajān (a ‘long bat, curved at one end, with which horsemen strike the ball in the game of horse-shinty’, i.e. polo, Steingass s.v.)
and advocates it above every other time of exercise.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Covenant ( Tafsīr K. ʿahd Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis iusiurandum commentarius . Fichtner 390. Cf. extracts in Arabic in Chs. 1 and 2.
It consists of one section.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Aphorisms ( Tafsīr K. al-fuṣūl li-Abuqrāṭ ).
Hippocratis aphorismi et Galeni in eos commentarii . Fichtner 101* and 102*.
He composed it in seven sections.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Fractures ( Tafsīr K. al-kasr li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis librum de fracturis commentarii . Fichtner 110*.
He wrote it in three sections.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Reducing Dislocation ( Tafsīr K. radd al-khalʿ li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de articulis librum commentarii (Fichtner 105*), together with the De humero iis modis prolapso quos Hippocrates non vidit (Fichtner 106*), which is in effect part of it.
He wrote it in four sections.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Prognosis ( Tafsīr K. taqdimat al-maʿrifah li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis prognosticum commentarii . Fichtner 109*.
He wrote it in three sections.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Regimen in Acute Diseases ( Tafsīr K. tadbīr al-amrāḍ al-ḥāddah li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de victu acutorum commentaria . Fichtner 93*.
We have found three sections to the commentary, though in the Pinax Galen says he commented on it in five sections. These first three sections are a commentary on the genuine portion of the book; the remaining two are a commentary on the spurious portion.
Cf. On My Own Books 9.9 (Boudon-Millot, Galien ) ‘three on the genuine part of the book, two on additions to it’. As Ḥunayn explains ( Risālah 41 text, 33 trans.), the commentary on the genuine part of the book was translated into Arabic by ʿĪsā ibn Yaḥyā.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Ulcers ( Tafsīr K. al-qurūḥ li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de vulneribus et ulceribus librum commentarius . Fichtner 361.
He wrote it in one section.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Wounds to the Head ( Tafsīr K. jirāḥāt al-raʾs li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de capitis vulneribus librum commentarius . Fichtner 383.
It consists of one section.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Epidemics ( Tafsīr K. Abīdīmiyā li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis epidemiarum librum primum commentarii , In Hippocratis epidemiarum librum secundum commentarii, In Hippocratis epidemiarum librum tertium commentarii , In Hippocratis epidemiarum librum sextum commentarii : Fichtner 96–100*. Arabic for Bks 1 and 2 at CMG Suppl. Or. V 1 and V 2 (ed. Vagelpohl).
He commented on the first book in three sections, the second in six, the third in three,
Ḥunayn (recension ‘A’) carelessly has ‘three’ for Bk 2 and ‘six’ for Bk 3, but IAU either drew on recension ‘B’ or On My Own Books 9.10.
and the sixth in eight sections. This is the extent of his commentary. The remaining three books – i.e. four, five, and seven – were not given a commentary because, as he states, they are forgeries using Hippocrates’ language.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Humours ( Tafsīr K. al-akhlāṭ li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de humoribus librum commentarii . Fichtner 94. The Greek text printed in Kühn’s edition of Galen is a Renaissance forgery.
He wrote it in three sections.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Predictions ( Tafsīr K. taqdimat al-indhār li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis praedictionum librum primum commentarii . Fichtner 95*.
To this day I have not found a copy.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ In the Surgery ( Tafsīr K. qāṭyaṭriyyūn li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis librum de officina medici commentarii . Fichtner 111*; Arabic at CMG Suppl. Or. I (ed. Lyons).
He wrote it in three sections.

Commentary on Air, Water, and Dwelling-Places ( Tafsīr K. al-hawāʾ wa-l-māʾ wa-l-masākin li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de aere aquis locis librum commentarii . Fichtner 382.
He wrote this in three sections too.
MS B adds, ‘We have found some copies of the commentary also have it in four sections. However, the former arrangement is to be relied on’.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Nutrition ( Tafsīr K. al-ghidhāʾ li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis librum de alimento commentarii . Fichtner 92*.
He wrote it in four sections.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Nature of the Embryo ( Tafsīr K. ṭabīʿat al-janīn li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de natura pueri librum commentarius . Fichtner 384.
Ḥunayn says that, ‘For this book we have found no commentary in Galen’s own words nor have we found any statement in his Catalogue that he produced one. However, in the work he composed on Hippocrates’ knowledge of anatomy
See no. 27 above.
we came across a reference to a threefold division of the book. Galen notes that the first and third portions of it are spurious and not by Hippocrates but that the second portion is genuine. It was on this that Gessius of Alexandria wrote a commentary.
Gessius of Petra worked in Alexandria and died around 520; on him see Sezgin,
GAS
III , 160–161, Walbridge, Epitomes , p. xxxix; and below 5.2.1, 6.1.1 (superiority of his commentaries).
We have in fact found two commentaries on all three books together. One of these is in Syriac and bears the inscription that it is by Galen and in the translation of Sergius.
I.e. Sergius of Rēsh ʿAynā.
Upon examination we learnt that it was by Pelops.
The name is not secure, and Thessalus and Polybus have been proposed.
The other is in Greek and upon investigation we discovered it is by Soranus, who belonged to the Methodist sect. Ḥunayn translated most of the text into Arabic during the caliphate of Muʿtazz bi-llāh’.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Nature of Man ( Tafsīr K. ṭabīʿat al-insān ).
In Hippocratis de natura hominis librum commentarii . Fichtner 90*.
He composed it in two
Ḥunayn: ‘three’. As transmitted to us in Greek, the commentary is divided into three (ed. Mewaldt, CMG
V 9, 1) but only the first two are on De natura hominis , while the third is on De diaeta salubri . Cf. recension ‘B’ where Ḥunayn writes, ‘in three sections according to my recollection of it’.
sections.
list.label: 102a.
list.item:
The Identity of Hippocrates’ Views in his Nature of Man and in his Other Works ( K. fī anna raʾy Abuqrāṭ fī K. ṭabīʿat al-insān wa-fī sāʾir kutubihi wāḥid ).
Quod in aliis scriptis suis videatur Hippocrates eandem habere sententiam cum eo de natura hominis . Fichtner 426. This work is additional to those listed in Ḥunayn’s Risālah as transmitted.
He composed it in three sections. Galen says he authored it after the commentary on Nature of Man on being informed that certain people objected to that book by alleging that it was not by Hippocrates.

The Best Physician Must also Be a Philosopher ( K. fī anna l-ṭabīb al-fāḍil yajibu an yakūna faylasūfan ).
Quod optimus medicus sit quoque philosophus . Fichtner 3*. Arabic at ‘Graeco-Arabic-Studies’ (ed. Bachmann).
It consists of a single section.

Authentic and Inauthentic Works of Hippocrates ( K. fī kutub Abuqrāṭ al-ṣaḥīḥah wa-ghayr al-ṣaḥīḥah ). It consists of a single section.
De Hippocratis scriptis genuinis . Fichtner 244.

An Enquiry into the Correctness of Quintus’ Critique of the Hippocratics for Advocating the Four Qualities ( K. fī l-baḥth ʿan ṣawāb mā thalaba bihi Quwīnṭus aṣḥāb Abuqrāṭ alladhīna qālū bi-l-kayfiyyāt al-arbaʿ ).
Not in Fichtner. See Sezgin,
GAS
III , 137 no. 147. For Quintus, see n. 161.
Ḥunayn says that ‘I do not know the truth or otherwise of Galen’s authorship. I do not think it has been translated.’

Prolonged Sleep according to the Views of Hippocrates ( K. fī l-subāt ʿalā raʾy Abuqrāṭ ).
De comate secundum Hippocratem . Fichtner 55*.
Ḥunayn again remarks that, ‘The story of this book is like the story of the book’ he discussed before.

Hippocrates’ Terminology ( K. fī alfāẓ Abuqrāṭ ).
Linguarum seu dictionum exoletarum Hippocratis explicatio ( Glossarium ). Fichtner 116*.
Ḥunayn says that, ‘This book also consists of one section. The aim is to explain unusual Hippocratic terminology throughout the corpus. It is useful for those who read Greek; but those reading in other languages have no need of it, and it would be completely impossible to translate’.

The Substance of the Soul according to the Views of Asclepiades ( K. fī jawhar al-nafs mā hiya ʿalā raʾy Asqalībiyādhas ).
De substantia animae secundum Asclepiadem . Fichtner 332. Cf. Sezgin,
GAS
III , 55. Asclepiades (late 2nd/early 1st cent. BC ) established Greek medicine at Rome; some of his views led to Methodism; cf. Ch. 4.11.2, n. 214.
It consists of a single section.

Medical Experience ( K. fī l-tajribah al-ṭibbiyyah ).
De experientia medica . Fichtner 235. For the Arabic translation, see Walzer, Experience .
It consists of a single section. In it he relates the arguments of the Empiricists and Dogmatists against one another.

An Exhortation to Study Medicine ( K. fī l-ḥathth ʿalā taʿallum al-ṭibb ).
Adhortatio ad artes addiscendas ( Protepticus ). Fichtner 1*.
It consists of a single section. Ḥunayn says that in this work Galen ‘copies Menodotus’ book;
Menodotus was an empiricist physician of the early to mid 2nd cent., strongly opposed to Methodism. See On My Own Books 12 with the notes of Boudon-Millot, Galien and Boudon, Galien, Exhortation 35–42. In the present state of knowledge the translation here is uncertain. The words ‘Ḥunayn says … Menodotus’ book’ are absent from recension ‘A’ and are taken from recension ‘B’. Ḥunayn would have known from On My Own Books 12.1 that Galen had written a work on Menodotus’ To Severus , but he could have known no details of it. (In the Arabic of On My Own Books the text of 12.1 has ‘Book on the Introduction of Menodotus, eleven sections’; Boudon-Millot wrongly reports a change in the Arabic to ‘dix’). The Adhortatio itself contains no reference to Menodotus in the surviving section (but the lost second part presumably did mention him). The best interpretation of the Greek of On My Own Books 12.3, where the Adhortatio is listed, reads: ‘ On Menodotus’ “To Severus”, Protreptic to Medicine .’ The Arabic for this has ‘a section [ maqālah ] from the book of Menodotus, On Enthusiasm for Medicine ’.
it is an excellent, useful, and attractive work.’

The Tenets of Empiricism ( K. fī jumal al-tajribah ).
Subfiguratio empirica . Fichtner 223.
It consists of a single section.

Examination of the Best of Physicians ( K. fī miḥnat afḍal al-atibbāʾ ).
De optimo medico cognoscendo . Fichtner 232. CMG Suppl. Or. IV (ed. Iskandar, Examinations ). There is no trace of the work in Greek. See above 5.1.18, 29.
It consists of a single section.

His Own Views ( K. fīmā yaʿtaqiduhu raʾyan ).
De propriis placitis . Fichtner 309*.
It consists of a single section. He recounts what he knew and what he did not.

Medical Terms ( K. fī l-asmāʾ al-ṭibbiyyah ).
De nominibus medicis . Fichtner 284. Arabic at ‘Graeco-Arabic-Studies’ (ed. Meyerhof/Schacht).
His aim is to clarify the senses in which physicians use the terms they employ. He wrote it in five sections. We have found translated into Arabic only the first section in a version by Ḥubaysh al-Aʿsam.

On Proof ( K. al-burhān ).
De demonstratione . Fichtner 209.
He composed this book in fifteen sections. His aim is to show that the method used to demonstrate a proposition proceeds by necessary steps. For this is Aristotle’s aim in the fourth book of his Logic .
I.e. the Posterior Analytics , where Aristotle defines ‘demonstration ( apodeixis ) as deduction that is concerned with scientific knowledge ( sullogismos epistēmoniskos )’ (71b18). The keen interest in De demonstratione for Ḥunayn and others is explained by Galen’s vast output on the topic of apodeixis (see On My Own Books 14, Boudon-Millot, Galien ) and the prospect of linking the great physician and the great philosopher. A copyist like Gc, who otherwise heavily abbreviates much of the list of Galen’s books, shows that the romance of Ḥunayn’s searchings had an appeal of its own.
Ḥunayn says that, ‘To the present day none of my contemporaries has managed to locate a complete copy of On Proof in Greek despite the fact that Jibrīl
I.e. Jibrīl ibn Bukhtīshūʿ the celebrated physician of Hārūn al-Rashīd; see 5.1.16.1.
had made a great effort to look for it and I too put all my energy into the search, combing the lands of al-Jazīrah, al-Shām,
In modern terms these two regions comprise northern Iraq and south-eastern Turkey, and Syria and Lebanon.
and the whole of Palestine and Egypt till I reached Alexandria. I found no trace except for about half of it at Damascus but the sections were not consecutive or complete. Jibrīl also found sections from it and not all of them were the same as the ones found by me. Ayyūb
Job of Edessa (d. after 832); Ullmann, Medizin , 101–102. See IAU Chs. 8.22 and 9.7.
translated them for him. As for me, I had no desire to translate any of it without the prospect of being able to read the entire thing both because of its damaged and defective condition and because my soul longed to discover a complete version. But later I translated what I had into Syriac. This comprised a small portion of the second section, most of the third, and approximately half of the fourth from the beginning together with the ninth except for part of the beginning, which had fallen out. I came across all the other sections bar the fifteenth, which was defective at the end. ʿĪsā ibn Yaḥyā
ʿĪsā ibn Yaḥyā ibn Ibrāhīm, a student of Ḥunayn’s: Sezgin,
GAS
III , 257, cf. Ullmann, Medizin , 30, 57, and IAU Chs. 8.35 and 9.5. IAU may not have realized that this last sentence is an addition where ‘he’ = Ḥunayn.
translated what he found from section eight
Risālah : ‘two’.
to section eleven and Isḥāq ibn Ḥunayn made an Arabic version of twelve to fifteen.’

Hypothetical premises ( K. fī l-qiyāsāt al-waḍʿiyyah ).
De principiis ex suppositione , Fichtner 303. Arabic qiyāsāt = Greek archai .
It consists of one section.

The Structure of the Arts ( K. fī qiwām al-ṣināʿāt ).
De constitutione artium (Fichtner 6*, 180), a work in three books ( On My Own Books 14.22, Art of Medicine 37.6 ed. Boudon, Galien, Exhortation ), from which there survives only the last on medicine ( De constitutione artis medicae ), where Galen refers to the work being in two parts (i.e. medicine and the other crafts). In it Galen discussed various professions (arts/crafts) from the perspective of their Aristotelian telos or ultimate end (cf. Art of Medicine 1.2). The unknown dedicatee – Patrophilus – is commended for his love of apodeixis and methodos . It is this that explains the inclusion of the work in On My Own Books in a section devoted to ‘demonstration’. The ingenious alternative explanation by Rescher, Galen and the Syllogism Ch. 1 (cf. Lamoreaux, 118), that the word technē in the Greek title (περὶ τῆς τῶν τεχνῶν συστάσεως) is used in a technical philosophical sense as part of Galen’s vocabulary of logic, essentially meaning a ‘figure’ or ‘construction’, is without foundation.
Ḥunayn says that he had found only ‘fragments’ of this book in Greek.

A Man’s Ability to Know the Errors of his Soul ( K. fī taʿarruf al-insān ʿuyūb nafsihi ).
De propriorum animi cuiuslibet affectuum dignotione et curatione (Fichtner 29*) and De animi cuiuslibet peccatorum dignotione et curatione (Fichtner 30*).
It consists of two sections. Ḥunayn says that he had found in Greek ‘only a defective copy of one section.’

Character Traits ( K. al-akhlāq ).
De moribus . Fichtner 412. It is not clear IAU knew the work directly; cf. 5.1.6, 12, 34 no. 8.
It consists of four sections. His aim is to describe types, causes, and signs of characters and the way to deal with them.

Avoiding Distress ( M. fī ṣarf al-ightimām ).
De dolore evitando . Fichtner 217*. Cf. 5.1.26 (under the alternative title Fī nafy al-ghamm ).
He wrote this for a man who asked him how it could be that he had never seen him distressed by the loss of all the possessions he had deposited in the great storehouses when these burnt down in Rome, and so he set out for him the reason for this and showed when distress is justified and when it is not.

The Best People Can Derive Benefit from their Enemies ( M. fī anna akhyār al-nās qad yantafiʿūna bi-aʿdāʾihim ).
Fichtner 162. See 5.1.30. The work survives in a handful of quotations in Arabic only; Ullmann, Medizin , 64 no. 117.

Plato’s Discussion of Medical Science in his Book Known as Timaeus ( K. fīmā dhakara Aflāṭun fī kitābihi l-maʿrūf bi-Ṭīmāwus min ʿilm al-ṭibb ).
In Platonis Timaeum commentarii . Fichtner 396. Cf. no. 185.
It consists of four sections.

The Properties of the Soul Follow the Mixture of the Body ( K. fī anna quwā l-nafs tābiʿah li-mizāj al-badan ).
Quod animi mores corporis temperamenta sequantur . Fichtner 28*. Arabic at ‘Graeco-Arabic-Studies’ (ed. Biesterfeldt); cf. Biesterfeldt, Galens Traktat .
It consists of a single section. His aim is clear from the title.

Summaries of Plato’s Books ( K. jawāmiʿ kutub Aflāṭūn ).
Platonicorum dialogorum compendia . Fichtner 415; cf. Fichtner 158, 159, 160; Gutas, ‘Tradition arabe’.
Ḥunayn says that, ‘Among writings of this sort
I.e. Platonic philosophy. Ḥunayn refers to his rubric before no. 122, which IAU misses out along with other such headers.
I came across another volume, which consists of four sections out of eight written by Galen. It contains summaries of Plato’s books. In section one there are summaries of five Platonic works: Cratylus on names, Sophist on division, Politicus
Both our recensions of Ḥunayn show confusion between Plato’s Politikos and Aristotle’s Analutika (so also MS A of IAU ).
on the statesman, Parmenides on forms, and Euthedemus . In section two there are summaries on four sections of Plato’s Republic ,
Cf. 5.1.12.3 above.
and in section three a summary of the six remaining sections together with one on the book called Timaeus , which concerns the study of nature. In section four he summarizes the principal ideas of the twelve sections of Plato’s Laws .’

That the Prime Mover Does Not Move ( K. fī anna l-muḥarrik al-awwal lā yataḥarrak ).
In primum movens immotum . Fichtner 398. Cf. 5.1.14.
It consists of a single section.

Introduction to Logic ( K. al-mudkhal ilā l-manṭiq ).
Institutio logica . Fichtner 402.
It consists of one section. He sets out the topics essential for beginners that they will benefit from by learning (the art of) proof.

The Number of Syllogisms ( M. fī ʿadad al-maqāyīs ).
De syllogismorum numero . Fichtner 333.

Commentary on the Second Book of Aristotle , which is called Peri Hermēneias ( tafsīr al-kitāb al-thānī min kutub Arisṭūṭālīs wa-huwa lladhī yusammā bārīmīniyās ).
In librum de interpretatione Aristotelis commentarii . Fichtner 392.
It consists of three sections. Ḥunayn says that he had discovered ‘a defective copy’.

Requirements for Someone who Makes Errors in Speech ( K. fīmā yalzamu lladhī yalḥanu fī kalāmihi ).
Ad eos qui voce soloecissantes reprehendunt . Fichtner 136.
It consists of seven sections. Ḥunayn says that he had found only one and that he had not translated it.

div.p:
Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq says,
At this point IAU turns to a short work by Ḥunayn on material ‘not listed by Galen in the Catalogue of his books’. He starts his quotation with the second preface on books that were falsely ascribed to Galen (the first part of the work deals with genuine titles that had not been mentioned in On My Own Books ). See Meyerhof, ‘Über echte und unechte Schriften’; text and translation also in Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq, Neue Materialen , 84–98. IAU was using a version of the work that offers some differences from the sole manuscript known to us. He follows the book titles closely except that he puts the word maqālah (‘treatise’) in first position whereas Ḥunayn for the most part puts it last, a change that causes IAU to make two titles (nos. 136–137) out of one in Ḥunayn. IAU probably only knew the works in this section from Ḥunayn’s pamphlet. Entries in Fichtner, Sezgin,
GAS
III , and Ullmann, Medizin , are referred to where they exist. In some cases they add little to Ḥunayn.
‘We have also come across a number of books with Galen’s name in the title but not by him. Rather, some of them are snippets of Galenic phrases arranged by other people to make books. In other cases they are by authors prior to Galen and later on someone put Galen’s name in the title. He did this either out of a desire to multiply the number of Galenic books in his possession no-one else owned or because of a lack of sense that it is a constant attribute of fools such that when they come across a book with a number of sections to it and find the first of these begins with a certain person’s name, they assume all the other sections are by the same person. This is why we find many sections in books by Rufus that have Galen’s name in the title – for example, his treatise On Jaundice ( M. fī l-yaraqān )’.
The text of Ḥunayn has ‘theriac’. See no. 152 below for the Galenic treatise on jaundice. Ḥunayn is probably referring to Rufus’ On Poisons (Ullmann, Medizin , 75 no. 25, Sezgin,
GAS
III , 66 no. 14).
Ḥunayn continues, ‘Those sections of books where we find Galen in the title have a quality of language that is quite alien to Galen’s hallmark style and the force of the thought in them is quite different from Galen’s own beliefs.’
These titles are:

list.item:
On the Leaders of the Sects ( M. fī aʾimmat al-firaq ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 139 no. 160.

On Types Established by Hippocrates ( M. fī l-rusūm allatī rasamahā Buqrāṭ ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131 no. 118. Cf. titles nos. 65, 147.

Treatise Entitled “The Physician, by Galen” ( M. mawsūmah al-ṭabīb li-Jālīnūs ). Galen in fact mentions it at the start of his Catalogue,
On My Own Books 1.1 ἐπεγέγραπτο μὲν γὰρ Γαληνοῦ [ MSS Γαληνὸς] ἰατρός, ‘the title was “Galen’s Physician” (or “Galen, Physician”).’
where he informs us that it was falsely attributed and inauthentic.
Cf. Fichtner 89* (the Ps.-Galenic Introductio sive medicus , known in Greek as Galen’s “Physician”: An Introduction (Γαληνοῦ ἰατρός· εἰσαγωγή); see also Sezgin,
GAS
III , 139 n. 154, esp. Petit, Le Médecin. Introduction , p. cvii n. 153, 107 n. 1). There is no necessary link between the surviving Introductio and the work mentioned by Galen in On My Own Books .

On the Art ( M. fī l-ṣināʿah ). I refer not to the famous treatise designated by this title, the authenticity of which is well known,
Cf. no. 4, which is classified in the Arabic as a kitāb (‘book’) rather than a maqālah (‘treatise’) as here.
but to a different one that is falsely attributed. This author’s language is slapdash and careless.

On Bones ( K. fī l-ʿiẓām ). I refer not to the authentic treatise on this subject but to another one.
Cf. no. 7, which is classified in the Arabic as a kitāb rather than a maqālah as here.
The author’s ability is far weaker than the level of that class (of books).

On Definitions ( K. fī l-ḥudūd ).
Definitiones medicae . Fichtner 120*.

Treatise in a question and answer format ( M. ʿalā ṭarīq al-masʾalah wa-l-jawāb ).
IAU has separated nos. 136 and 137. Ḥunayn has ‘In question and answer format a treatise on …’; but IAU ’s habit of beginning each entry with maqālah has led him to create two works, even though the first is a nonsense. Contrast no. 139 where he avoids splitting a single work and creating a maqālah on Homer and maqālatān (‘two sections’) on Galen’s style by calling the whole a kitāb .

On the Causes of Breathing ( M. fī ʿilal al-tanaffus ).
Cf. no. 37, which is classified in the Arabic as a kitāb rather than a maqālah as here.
It is short and fragmentary.
On Natural Language ( M. fī l-kalām al-ṭabīʿī ).

On Medicine according to the Views of Homer ( K. fī l-ṭibb ʿalā raʾy Ūmīrus ).
De medicina apud Homerum . Fichtner 268.
It consists of two sections. The phraseology and language of both of them are very similar to Galen’s. However, the point of the argument is weak in both sections and moreover at the end of section two the views are improbable and quite unlike the Galenic system.

On the Humours according to the Views of Hippocrates ( M. fī l-akhlāṭ ʿalā raʾy Abuqrāṭ ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 130 no. 114, cf. Fichtner 122.

Investigation into whether the Parts of the Foetus Generated in the Womb are Created Simultaneously or Not ( M. yubḥathu fīhā hal aʿḍaʾ al-janīn al-mutawallid fī l-raḥim tatakhallaqu kulluhā maʿan am lā ).
An omnes partes animalis, quod procreatur, fiant simul . Fichtner 144.

Investigation into whether the Foetus is Alive or Not in the Womb ( M. yubḥathu fīhā hal al-janīn fī l-raḥim ḥayawān am lā ).
An animal sit quod est in utero . Fichtner 117*.

Treatise arguing that the soul does not die ( M. fī anna l-nafs lā tamūt ).
Cf. Fichtner 174 De anima .

On Milk ( M. fī l-laban ).
De lacte . Fichtner 262. Note also Rufus’ On Drinking Milk ( Kitāb Shurb al-Laban or Kitāb al-Laban , as we have it here in IAU , cf. Ch. 4.1.10.2 title no. 21): Sezgin,
GAS
III , 66 no. 15, 412, Ullmann, Medizin , 75 no. 23.

On Drying Out the Flesh ( M. fī tajfīf al-laḥm ).
Ḥunayn and some MSS of IAU (but not AGaR) read ‘lightening’ rather than ‘drying out’, a very easy change. Cf. Fichtner 272, Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131 no. 127 for the suggestion that the medieval Latin De minutionibus (extant in manuscript) represents a translation of On the Lightening of the Flesh . This would be easier if the title were a corruption of De ⟨de/di⟩minutionibus , as Klaus-Dietrich Fischer suggests to me.

On Types ( M. fī l-rusūm ). This is different from the genuine treatise above and inferior to it in authority.
Cf. no. 131.

On Urine ( M. fī l-bawl ).
De urinis . Fichtner 127*.

Treatise refuting the followers of the third sect on the passage where he sets out the causes of diseases during their establishment ( M. fī l-radd ʿalā aṣḥāb al-firqah al-thālithah fī l-mawḍiʿ alladhī yadhkuru fīhi asbāb al-amrāḍ ʿinda tarkībihā ).
The third sect is the upstart sect of Methodism as distinguished from the traditional Empiricists and Rationalists/Dogmatics. See Sezgin,
GAS
III , 139 no. 159 with n. 2 for the unlikely suggestion that this work is the De methodica secta (see 5.1.19 with n. 128) mentioned in On My Own Books 13.

Treatise arguing that Hippocrates surpassed everybody in his knowledge of the phases of disease ( M. fī anna Abuqrāṭ sabaqa l-nās jamīʿan fī maʿrifat al-awqāt ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 139 no. 157.

On the Causes of Illnesses ( M. fī asbāb al-ʿilal ).
Cf. Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131–132 no. 129. Ḥunayn has ‘relapses’ for ‘illnesses’.

On Jaundice ( M. fī l-yaraqān ).
De cura icteri . Fichtner 276. See also Ullmann, Medizin , id., Die Gelbsucht .

div.p:
Ḥunayn says,
At the end of the same work.
‘Titles we find mentioned by Galen in his books but not recorded in his Catalogue and of which no copy is available’:

list.item:
On Humours according to the Views of Praxagoras ( M. fī l-akhlāṭ ʿalā raʾy Braksāghūrus ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 139 no. 156. Our MSS spell B-ū-k-s-ā-gh-ū-r-s ; contrast 5.1.10.1 above ( B-r-k-s-ā-gh-ū-r-s ) and Ḥunayn ( F-r-k-s-ā-gh-ū-r-s ).

On People who Require Phlebotomy in the Spring ( M. fī man yaḥtāju fī l-rabīʿ ilā l-faṣd ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131 no. 128.

div.p:
This is the sum total of Galen’s books, authentic or attributed, that I have been able to list following the entries in Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq’s book on his discoveries or translations into Arabic. He made this when he was 48 years old. Since he lived till 70, he must have come across many additional works of Galen’s that were translated into Arabic, just as we have found many of Galen’s books and others ascribed to him in translations by Ḥunayn or other people and of which there is absolutely no record in his above cited work.
Ḥunayn’s statement that he wrote his main bibliographical work when he was 48 refers to the original, lost edition published 856. IAU has not remembered or noticed that he then speaks of a new edition published 10 years after that. The surviving ‘A’ and ‘B’ recensions are revised versions of this second edition.
Examples of these are:

list.item:
Commentary on Hippocrates’ Pains in Women ( Tafsīr K. awjāʿ al-nisāʾ li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de mulierum affectibus commentarius . Fichtner 386; Sezgin,
GAS
III , 41–42 no. 17, 124 no. 85.
It consists of a single section.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Sevens ( Tafsīr K. al-asābīʿ li-Abuqrāṭ ).
In Hippocratis de septimanis commentarii . Fichtner 388.

Commentary on Hippocrates’ Regimen for Healthy People ( Tafsīr K. tadbīr al-asiḥḥāʾ li-Abuqrāṭ ). It consists of a single section.
In Hippocratis vel Polybi opus de salubri victus ratione commentarius . Fichtner 91*. See below no. 184.

Treatments for Sicknesses ( K. mudāwāt al-asqām ); it is also known as Medicine for the Poor ( Ṭibb al-masākīn ),
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 129 no. 104. Treatments for Sicknesses is in fact the title of a therapeutic treatise, known in Arabic, by the important 4th cent. physician, Philagrius: Ullmann, Medizin , 79 no. 1 Mudāwāt al-aqsām , cf. p. 81, Sezgin,
GAS
III , 155 no. 3; it is perhaps identical with the Signs of Sicknesses recorded as title no. 2 in the list of Philagrius’ books below, though this work is in five sections.
and consists of two sections.

Bone Setting ( K. fī l-jabr ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 130 no. 116.
It consists of three sections.

Sudden Death ( K. fī l-mawt al-sarīʿ ).
De morte subitanea . Fichtner 278.
It consists of one section.

Treatise on Enemas and Colic ( M. fī l-ḥuqan wa-l-qawlanj ).
De clysteribus et colica . Fichtner 194.

Treatise on Sleep, Insomnia, and Emaciation ( M. fī l-nawm wa-l-yaqaẓah wa-l-ḍumūr ).
De somno et vigilia . Fichtner 328.

Treatise on Prohibiting Burial Within Twenty-Four Hours ( M. fī taḥrīm al-dafn qabl arbaʿ wa-ʿishrīn sāʿah ).
De prohibenda sepultura . Fichtner 305. See ʿUbayd Allāh ibn Bukhtīshūʿ, On Apparent Death . On the topos as a special variety of prognosis, see Bürgel, Ärztliches Leben 266–272.

Treatise on the Providence of the Creator – Mighty and Glorious! – for Mankind ( M. fī ʿināyat al-khāliq ʿazza wa-jalla bi-l-insān ).
Fichtner 135.

To Queen Fīlāfūs on the Secrets of Women ( R. ilā Fīlāfūs al-malikah fī asrār al-nisāʾ ).
See next note.

To Qusṭānis the Chamberlain on the Secrets of Men ( R. ilā Qusṭānis al-Qahramān fī asrār al-rijāl ).
De secretis feminarum et virorum . Fichtner 322.

Secret Remedies ( K.fī l-adwiyah al-maktūmah ). He gives us hints and suggestions of these remedies in his works. It is in a single section.
Liber secretorum ad Monteum . Fichtner 409. According to Ullmann, Medizin , 60 no. 103 Secret Remedies was an alternative title of the book known as Advice for Monks and the opening remarks to the addressee M-w-t-w-s show that the secrecy lies in a restricted dissemination. Sezgin,
GAS
III , 126 no. 91 and 129 no. 102 distinguishes the two and names the addressee of Advice for Monks as ‘Julianus’.
Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq says,
The source of the quotation is unknown.
‘In this book Galen intended to describe all the secret and special remedies he had assembled over his lifetime and had successfully tried out on many occasions but had concealed and kept back from most people. He gave instruction in them to only a select number of practitioners of the art who possessed the right qualities and the soundest judgment. Someone other than myself made a version of it but made a mess by adding material that was not present and omitting things he did not understand how to translate. I applied myself to it so far as opportunity and ability allowed, compared it with my own considerable experience, and made an Arabic version for Abū Jaʿfar Muḥammad ibn Mūsā’.
For Ḥunayn’s patron and his family, see
EI
2 art. ‘Mūsā, Banū’ (D.R. Hill).
On Extracting Liquids from Plants ( M. fī stikhrāj miyāh al-ḥashāʾish ).

On Substitute Drugs ( M. fī abdāl al-adwiya ).
De succedaneis . Fichtner 133*. Not genuine.
A collection of sayings in which he outlines the influence of the sun, moon, and stars.

On Colours ( M. fī l-alwān ).
Cf. Sezgin,
GAS
III , 47 no. 18 for a work of this name allegedly ascribed in the Arabic tradition to Hippocrates.

Summary of his work On Proof ( Fī l-burhān ).
Cf. no. 115.

Nature of the Embryo ( K. ṭabīʿat al-janīn ).
Cf. the work of this title by Hippocrates, De natura pueri ( De natura foetus , etc.). Fichtner, Corpus Hippocraticum 46* (there is an edition of the Arabic translation by Lyons & Mattock, Hippocrates, Ajinna ). See Ch. 4.1.9.1 title no. 1.

Refutation of Archigenes on the Pulse ( K. al-radd ʿalā Arkhījānis fī l-nabḍ ).
Cf. title no. 67.

Prolonged Sleep ( K. fī l-subāt ).
Cf. no. 106.

Abridgment of his Properties of Foods ( Ikhtiṣāruhu li-kitābihi fī quwā l-aghdhiyah ).
See no. 74 above.

Erasistratus’ Slurs ( K. fī l-afkār al-musfiyah li-Arāsisṭrāṭus ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 139 no. 158.
On the Uses of Theriac ( K. manāfiʿ al-tiryāq ).
On Juices ( M. fī l-kaymūsāt ).

Discussion of flavours ( Kalām fī l-ṭuʿūm ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131 no. 125.

On the Bite of a Rabid Dog ( R. fī ʿaḍḍat al-kalb al-kalib ).
Cf. title no. 13 of the works ascribed to Philagrius below.

Cohesive Causes ( K. fī l-asbāb al-māsikah ).
An alternative title to no. 59.

Commentary on Polybus’ Regimen for Healthy People ( Tafsīr K. Fūlūbus fī tadbīr al-aṣiḥḥāʾ ).
See no. 157. The Regimen for Healthy People was ascribed either to Hippocrates or his son-in-law Polybus.

Commentary on the Medical Parts of Plato’s Book Entitled Timaeus ( Tafsīr mā fī K. Falāṭun al-musammā Tīmāwus min ʿilm al-ṭibb ).
Cf. no. 122.

Cleansing Drugs ( K. fī l-adwiyah al-munaqqiyah ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 129 no. 103.

Intestines ( K. fī al-amʿāʾ ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131 no. 123.

Improving and Protecting Voices from Damage ( K. fī taḥsīn al-aṣwāt wa-nafy l-āfāt ʿanhā ).
Sezgin,
GAS
III , 131 no. 126.

div.p:
In conclusion I would note that Galen certainly wrote many other books that translators did not find or that were lost in the course of time, in particular those mentioned in the second section of Galen’s catalogue of his works called the Pinax .
Title no. 1 in the list of Galen’s works, where allusion is also made to the division into two.
Should anyone wish to refer to their titles or to Galen’s aim in each of them, he may consult this book.

p.hi:
[5.2.1]
For ‘Among the famous physicians … Oribasius the author of handbooks’ cf. Dunlop, Ṣiwān al-ḥikmah § 25 ll. 380–386. The source of both passages is Isḥāq ibn Ḥunayn’s history of physicians. IAU ’s text is closer to Isḥāq (Rosenthal, ‘Iṣḥāq b. Ḥunayn’, 69–70/79–80) than that of the Ṣiwān as transmitted.

div.p:
Among the famous physicians following Galen’s death or near to him were the Alexandrians Stephanus, Nicolaus, Gessius, and Marinus; these four are among the commentators on Galen’s books, and summarized and abridged them and shortened what he said;
The four are associated in the Arabic tradition with the composition of the Summaria Alexandrinorum, the summaries (or rather excerpts with comments and notes) of the sixteen books of Galen that formed the Alexandrian curriculum, some of them being an amalgamation of several separate treatises (cf. 5.137 titles 8, 14, 16). Only Gessius (Γέσιος or Γέσσιος), a late 5th c. physician and philosopher of great fame and wealth (e.g. Suda γ 207), is known with certainty (Watts, ‘The Enduring Legacy’); but there are works attributed to Palladius and Stephanus (on whom see Wolska-Conus, ‘Stéphanos’). Nicolaus is Anqīlāwus in the Arabic of IAU and our other sources and the Greek behind it is unclear but is suggested by Ibn al-Qifṭī, Taʾrīkh al-ḥukamāʾ , p. 356.18 wa-qīlu Nīqulāʾus ʿan Anqīlāʾus (cf. note d. to the edition: V Nīqūlāwus ); however, no medical Nicolaus is known. See further Ch. 6.1.1 for the list of seven Alexandrians drawn from Ibn Buṭlān (Schacht & Meyerhof, Medico-Philosophical Controversy , 93–94 English, 59–60 Arabic), which omits Marinus and includes Theodosius (absent from Ibn Buṭlān as transmitted to us but probably ultimately identical with his Persius; see Ch. 6.1.1 n. 5), and also includes John the Grammarian, to whom IAU devotes much space in Ch. 6. On all these issues see recently Walbridge, Epitomes , pp. xxxix–xl. On the question of the origin of the Summaries in the context of the curriculum and discussion of the authors, see Sezgin,

Oribasius was a major figure in 4th cent. medicine and was close to Julian the Apostate. He died around 400. For this entry IAU follows Ibn al-Nadīm, Fihrist (Sayyid) 2/1:283, (Tajaddud) 350, almost word for word. See also Ch. 1.7. n. 80.

Paul of Aegina wrote the last major medical encyclopaedia of antiquity in the mid-7th cent. It was based on Oribasius and his sources.

There was also Stephanus of Ḥarrān; Oribasius the Obstetrician,
Oribasius al-Qawābilī . Although IAU distinguishes him from Julian’s physician, Oribasius treated pregnancy and midwifery ( inter alia ) in Bk 5 of To Eustathius and it may well be that this material circulated separately.
